text: oh God hi everyone salt in the air Tano
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
Colin Stetson album when we were that
what wept for the sea this is a brand
new LP from saxophonist and minimalism
Maverick Colin Stetson first reviewed
this guy's music over a decade ago it
was part two in an impressive Trio of
Records his new history Warfare series
Colin came through with an impressive
amount of buzz off this LP but that has
since died down a little bit so maybe
it's worth reminding some of you what
makes Colin Stetson such a special
artist he is not your typical horn
player his career has mostly been spent
pushing the boundaries of the instrument
using continuous breathing techniques to
pull off these uninterrupted solo pieces
where he hypnotically Cycles through all
these gradually evolving arpeggios and
Melodies and on many tracks his
saxophone is miked in such a way where
you're hearing ever everything not just
the sound of the instrument and its
Spirit bouncing off the walls of
whatever room Colin is performing in but
also depending on the piece the inner
workings of the instrument too the
rhythmic clicks and Clacks of its Keys
Colin breathing these weird ghost notes
and overtones he gets blowing into the
sacks as he's playing even more
aggressively in a way that it sounds
like he's humming or singing through the
sacks either way the end result is
haunting it's otherworldly it's
beautiful and unlike any other sax
records out there you're going to hear
now with all that being said I think
Colin's very unique talents on the
instrument tend to guide his creative
process in a very specific way and as a
result there's not an incredible amount
of variety across his discography you
could kind of hear him painting himself
in a corner a little bit on his last
major solo release all this I do for
Glory however his collaboration with
Sarah neufeld from a while back was
fantastic and he has since spent a lot
of time actually scoring TV and films
film after film after film actually be
it Ari Astor's amazing hereditary the
recent Texas Chainsaw reboot or even the
menu which was released not that long
ago the guy's really putting in a lot of
work and he was especially prolific last
year with a solo drone album the void
Patrol collab with Elliot sharp Billy
Martin and Peyton McDonald apparently he
also had a hand in the Disney Among the
Stars soundtrack too damn Colin is
getting those Disney Dollars again the
guy is seemingly more and more
everywhere every year and in the midst
of all of these busy collaborations and
crossovers he has found the time to come
through with another huge large and in
charge ambitious solo album one where he
feels like he's playing to his strengths
for the most part going back to the old
Colin Stetson a bit giving us those raw
and dizzying minimalist sex pieces but
with some exciting little improvements
and additions to keep things interesting
be it the Thematic through lines you can
draw between the opening track the
lighthouse one to the lighthouse two
three four and five later on the lp my
favorite being The Crossover with
Scottish musician Rita hayambiel who
brings some stellar and heavy bagpipes
on her featured track which I think
makes sense because I've always thought
Colin the way he approaches the sacks it
is very bagpipe like there's also a
spellbinding spoken word piece led by
Irish singer and producer erlao Leonard
focusing in on this dramatically stated
poem that thematically wraps up a lot of
the records emotions and feelings not
just in terms of the pieces we're
hearing but their titles there are also
moments on this thing like passage which
does yes bring some extra
instrumentation into the fold even if
some of the chord progressions and
layering are a bit obvious and basic but
there's not many other tracks on this
thing bringing in a whole lot of extra
This Record is over an hour it's 16 Cuts
long and the bread and butter of this
thing is exactly the kind of insane
physically demanding sax performances
that Colin is known for just elevated or
intensified in some way shape or form
like the title track for example which
is classic Stetson all the way but
there's these bright and Heavenly tones
calling away very quietly very subtly in
the background that make the piece so
much more immersive plus with that close
sax miking you hear those bass notes
rhythmically pulsating along the
progression of the piece kind of keeping
Pace infliction is a much moodier piece
by comparison the grooves of this track
skip like a broken record or like a
limping monster slowly lurching toward
you the unsettling Vibes coming off this
one with the howling Ghost Notes just
calling away in the background only
intensify those feelings long before the
sky would open is the lengthiest piece
on this record at eight minutes and
while it does sound like many of the
winding pieces from new history Warfare
Volume 2 in a sense it also feels much
more far reaching and determined this
time around with some new sounds
entering the fold like these weird
fluttering bits that I have no idea how
Khan is doing that and furthermore those
fiery distorted sort of overtones Colin
is throwing in here and there just sound
even more aggressive than they have in
the past there's fireflies the speed and
intensity of this piece is absolutely
insane I'm just melting down at the
quickness that Colin is coming at the
sax with on this one this and Rhythm are
two of the most edge of your seat cuts
on the entire record then with the
surface and the light the more measured
pacing of this one along with the
elongated notes the slower progression
gives more the sensation of floating in
space then the miking and presentation
of Collins performance on behind the sky
involves all of these or really
aggressive noisy Mechanical Rhythm
sounds going off it sort of sounds like
there's a full percussion section
performing behind Colin there are some
strong final moments on this record as
well including the spoken word piece I
talked about earlier that I think ties
everything up for the most part very
nicely in a bow at the end of this poem
there is a gorgeous and Powerful
instrumental Ascent that creates a
wonderful finale and then the somber
clothes are safe with me is a sad and
chillingly beautiful moment on the
record which I think just goes to show
how much effort and thought Colin put
into of the overall progression and
sequencing of this album really
resulting in his most cohesive and
focused effort to date now with that
being said I'm not entirely sure this
thing needed to be over an hour in
length I don't know if there's quite
that much versatility to the tracklist
here there were at least a few tracks
that paled in comparison to others or
felt kind of extra or maybe slightly
redundant but the record is still easily
one of Colin's best and he's come
through again it's been a while and he's
come through with yet another enchanting
and unique solo effort I'm feeling a
strong eight on this album transition
